page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The landscape is determined by soil-type. On the ridge to the south sand and gravel extraction leaves pits, which are surrounded by heathland, with heather, gorse, bracken, small conifers and birches. In parts this heathland slopes down into bog, in others into conifer, rhododendron and birch copses with lines of deciduous trees. The valley lies between the small rivers, Bere Stream and Piddle, and is chalk-based with blackthorn, hazel, hawthorn and holly, scrub, ancient oakwoods, fine ash, beech and chestnut trees. Willows edge the water. Much of the valley is grassland, some damp meadows with clumps of rushes. Buildings include a modern Golf Clubhouse, old farm buildings, cottages of brick or cob and thatch, a small Victorian Chapel and a l9th century mansion.
